By volunteering for our 5k, the Undy Run/Walk you can help change that! We have found that by getting people talking about this disease, we can save lives. Date:Saturday, October 7 Location: Firefighter's Field, Roosevelt Island, NYC HOW WE NEED YOUR HELP THE DAY OF THE EVENT: -Early Shift- Set up expo area Registration and runner check in Food & Beverage Tent Kids Fun Zone -Later Shift- Water stations Course cheering Course marshaling Clean Up Event Photographer Please note we are also happy to validate or confirm any hours needed for school or community service. About The Colon Cancer Alliance: The Colon Cancer Alliance is a community that provides hope and support to patients and their families, while saving lives through prevention, research, and patient support services. www.ccalliance.org TO SIGN UP AS A VOLUNTEER, CONTACT: Joanna Anastasio, Special Events Coordinator janastasio@ccalliance.org 202.207.0267

10013.description: For many new immigrants, learning English is a first step to full participation in American society. Help them take that first step by becoming a volunteer teacher in English or Citizenship classes. English classes help students improve their communication skills. Citizenship classes help students prepare for the U.S. citizenship test. Volunteers work in teams to plan lessons and teach the class. This fun and rewarding experience gives you a chance to make a difference in the lives of others. Individuals with an interest in education careers are encouraged to apply. Requirements Must have good communication skills and a strong desire to help and work with new immigrants Prior teaching experience is preferred. Bilingual skills are a plus. We prefer volunteers who can commit to teaching at least two semesters Prospective volunteers must complete application and be interviewed. Volunteer Schedule: 9:30 am-11:30am (Tues or Thurs) 10:30 am-12:30 pm (Tues or Thurs) 1pm to 4pm (Saturday) 6:30pm to 8:30 pm (Mon, Tues or Wed) Fall 2017 - September 30, 2017 to December 16, 2017 Spring 2018 - March 4, 2018 to June 7, 2018 Summer 2018 - July 9, 2018 to August 18, 2018 Prospective volunteers must complete application and will be interviewed. Please contact us at cpanyc@cpanyc.org for an application OR apply on-line here: http://bit.ly/volunteerteacherapp For more information: http://bit.ly/VolunteerToTeachEnglishorCitizenshipClass

10013.description: Since 2001, the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation’s family-friendly 5K walk/run program has raised both awareness and funds to support urgent multiple myeloma research. Today, the series is held annually in thirteen cities and participation offers hope, camaraderie and knowledge sharing within our myeloma community and beyond. We’ll be at Hudson River Park, Pier 97 on Saturday, October 21st, and need your help in making this year’s event a great day for our patients as well as their friends and family members! Volunteers can assist in a variety of ways, serving as part of the Welcome Team, Course Team, Event Team or Flex Team. Volunteers will also receive a free t-shirt on the day of the race! Groups welcome! To register, please click the link below: https://walkrun.themmrf.org/new-york-city/Account/Register Contact volunteers@themmrf.org with questions or for more information.

Responsibilities: Team leads will serve as main point of contact between site contact, team and Shine Board Work with facilitators and to create program and lesson plans Coordinate all team members - virtual and in-person facilitators, support, graphic designer and marketing specialist. Approve lesson plans and handouts. Provide regular progress updates on the program to site contact and Shine Board Ensure proper data collection for monitoring and evaluation. Qualifications: Experience managing multifunctional teams. 5+ years of prior project management experience. Highly organized and detailed oriented. Ability to make decisions and move processes forward. Timeframe: One-year Weekly commitment: 8 to 10 hours To apply: Send resumes to: general@shine-foundation.org

10013.description: We're seeking a fun and energetic person to volunteer as TZ the IDF Zebra at a Walk for PI event near you! This is the perfect volunteer opportunity for someone who: has an outgoing & creative personality with a willingness and desire to have fun; is willing to perform wacky activities & is good with spontaneous crowd-interaction; has good interpersonal skills (especially with children) & can work well with IDF staff members; is comfortable performing in front of a crowd (experience with dancing, acting, etc. is helpful but not required); is reliable and punctual; has strong non-verbal communication skills; is willing to represent the Immune Deficiency Foundation, our mission & core values, in a positive manner; is in good physical condition, between 5'6 - 5'10 tall & able to work in a costume. Please note that while performing duties of this role, the volunteer will be constantly in costume. He/she must be able to move about the area during the event to interact and entertain attendees.
10013.title: Hey New York, Check Out This Unique Volunteer Opportunity!

10013.description: Lend a hand to support the Immune Deficiency Foundation’s (IDF) Walk for Primary Immunodeficiency!! This annual event raises awareness and funds to support people with primary immunodeficiency (PI) diseases. IDF is a national organization committed to serving individuals with primary immunodeficiency and their families. This year we are using a new online tool to sign-up volunteers for their shifts at the Walk. Here's how it works in 3 easy steps: Find the online sign-up sheets at http://signup.com/go/kzZULjf Choose the DATE and CITY that you would like to volunteer, then select the SHIFT that you are available to lend a hand. Sign up! It's easy - you will complete the volunteer registration form and review the volunteer waiver. Please note that anyone 18 or older should complete their own separate volunteer sign-up registration. Join us on Sunday, October 22, 2017 for our signature fundraising event at Foley Square. We are looking for event day volunteers, 12 years or older to assist in a variety of different areas, such as: registration, route support, set-up, clean-up, and much more! This is the perfect volunteer opportunity for families and groups! We have a variety of shifts to fit your busy schedule. 6:30a-8:30a 8:00a-12:00p 9:30a-1:00p ALL DAY (6:30a-1:00p) ATTENTION! PLEASE READ IF YOU ARE A GROUP LEADER. If you are a group leader with (5) or more volunteers, you must complete the Group Registration form instead of the online sign-up sheet. We can accommodate small groups of 5-10 people. If you have any questions or if you need a Group Registration form, please contact Evette Watson at ewatson@primaryimmune.org.
10013.title: Volunteer at the (New York) IDF Walk for Primary Immunodeficiency

10129.description: LoCation: I Have A Dream School @ PS 7 160 East 120th Street. Rm 238 New York, NY times: Every other Monday, 3:30-5:30pm Populations: Children ages 8-10 Mentors needed: 10 Mentoring USA's mission is to create sustained and supportive mentor relationships for underserved youth ages 7-21. Mentoring USA partners with schools, community centers, foster care agencies, and other non-profits. Mentors are matched with youth. With trained adult mentors who can guide in developing better self-esteem, creating healthy relationships, and making positive life choices, our underserved youth have the opportunity to grow up healthier. Mentors and mentees meet in a supervised environment at a set time and location. All sites are supported by MUSA Program Managers who work directly with Site Supervisors at each location to ensure that the programs run smoothly. HOW TO APPLY Contact: volunteering@mentoringusa.org All mentors must be 18 and older and willing to undergo a background check and screening. Step 1: Visit Mentoring USA's website: http://www.mentoringusa.org Step 2: Complete the Mentor Application: http://www.mentoringusa.org/become_a_mentor/Mentor_Application Step 3: Attend our New Mentor Training.
10129.title: Mentoring is rewarding - Your mentee is waiting - Become a Mentor – UPPER EAST SIDE NYC!

10128.description: Learning Through Art Volunteer Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum is seeking volunteers to support teaching artists in New York City public school classrooms where the Learning Through Art (LTA) program is implemented. LTA Volunteers should be enthusiastic about arts education/integration and able to make a commitment to assist a teaching artist one day each week for the duration of the 20-week residency. LTA places teaching artists in New York City public school classrooms, where they collaborate with teachers to create process-oriented art projects that examine ideas and themes related to the school curriculum. In these 20-week residencies, teaching artists introduce art techniques and concepts and encourage students to view, analyze, and discuss works of art. Founded in 1937, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation is dedicated to promoting the understanding and appreciation of art, architecture, and other manifestations of visual culture, primarily of the modern and contemporary periods. The Guggenheim realizes this mission through exceptional exhibitions, education programs, research initiatives, and publications. The Guggenheim strives to engage and educate an increasingly diverse international audience through its unique network of museums and partnerships. With nearly three million annual visitors worldwide, the Guggenheim and its network is one of the most visited cultural institutions in the world. Responsibilities of a LTA Volunteer include: Distribute all art materials to students as directed by teaching artist. Help to maintain an organized classroom throughout each session and manage clean-up and storage of materials. Photograph (when advised by teaching artist) students at work in the classroom. Photograph one individual work for each student in February/March to be included in the catalog and exhibition slide show. Assisting the teaching artist in hanging in-school exhibitions and other displays of student artwork throughout the year As advised by teaching artist, work with students one-on-one and in small groups as needed. Helping with LTA events as needed, including family days at the Guggenheim Museum This is a volunteer position. Volunteers receive invitations to Guggenheim programs, free admission to museums across the country, discounts at the Guggenheim restaurants and store and the opportunity to learn about art education, museum education and modern and contemporary art. If you have any questions, please feel free to email learningthroughart@guggenheim.org. Volunteer commitment is once weekly from approximately mid-October through early May. TO APPLY: Please complete the LTA volunteer application found at www.guggenheim.org/lta. Email with a cover letter and résumé to learningthroughart@guggenheim.org or mail to Learning Through Art, 1071 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10128.
10128.title: Learning Through Art Volunteer
10128.org: Solomon R Guggenheim Museum, Learning Through Art

10028.description: Enthusiastic volunteers are needed to introduce school children to art and museums. We will train you to give guided tours at the Brooklyn Museum of Art and Metropolitan Museum of Art, and to go into the classroom to prepare the students for their visit. Tours take place Monday through Friday, during the school year, between the hours of 10am and 1pm. ArtWorks volunteers are in 20 schools throughout the five boroughs and our classroom teachers love us!
10028.title: "Introduce Children to Art and Museums"

10029.description: DREAM, an award winning youth development program, is seeking volunteer tutors to provide academic support to our middle school after-school students in East Harlem and the South Bronx. Tutors work with youth individually and in small groups to help improve student success in class, increase subject-specific retention, and contribute to overall academic enrichment and development. What You’ll Do Support academic enrichment activities, including homework help and tutoring; Provide individualized and team-wide support all after-school program activities and initiatives; Serve as a role model and build positive relationships with youth; What We’re Looking For Strong command of one or more of the following academic subjects: English, Math, Science, and/or Social Studies Previous experience working with youth; Possess creativity, enthusiasm, initative, flexibility, and patience; Solid oral communication skills; Ability to make a consistent, weekly commitment; Bachelor’s Degree (a plus); 1-2 years previous tutoring experience (a major plus). Benefits Gain invaluable experience and opportunities for professional development at an award winning youth development program; Receive an optional professional reference upon completion of your service term; Join an incredible community of passionate staff and volunteers. Minimum Commitment: 1-2 hours per week for 3 months. When: Monday - Thursday 4pm-5pm, 4pm-6pm, or 5:30pm-6:30pm (time depends on tutor availability and program site assignment) DREAM provides equal opportunity for all volunteers.

10029.description: We need a Volunteer Photographer to do photography work at our non profit organization. We need good quality photography of our programs, to help tell our clients' stories. Perfect for a photography student who wants to explore their photography skills, and great for someone who wants to offer their expert photography skills to a non profit organization that relies on telling the important stories of the most vulnerable New Yorkers. Flexibly schedule; 2 - 4 hours a week. Please email tgough@lsafhs.org with your resume.
10029.title: URGENT! Volunteer Photographer Needed!

10029.description: The Carter Burden Network, a nonprofit leader in aging services in New York City, is looking for a bright, energetic Social Media and Marketing volunteer to join our Volunteer Services team this fall. The Social Media and Marketing volunteer will assist with CBN’s social media strategy, from routine daily and weekly postings to participating in the conception and execution of campaigns. This is a hands-on position, offering the opportunity to actively improve the way in which CBN communicates its message to the public. The ideal candidate will contribute creatively to new and ongoing projects. This is an unpaid position that is great for someone who is interested in learning the ins and outs of the nonprofit sector while building skills and adding valuable work experience to their resume. Responsibilities: * Occasionally attend events taking place at various CBN locations * Document senior and volunteer engagement and activities via digital photography * Create engaging, elevated copy and content for all CBN social media channels: Instagram, Facebook, Twitter * Build out CBN’s first month-to-month social media calendar * Document and track social influencer engagement with CBN’s social media * Research the social media practices of comparable social services non-profits to glean content ideas and best practices Qualifications: * Undergraduate students welcome * Fluent in social media (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram) and scheduling tools * Proficient in photography * Excellent communication, organizational, and time-management skills * Strong interest in writing and multimedia * Detail-oriented (have an eagle eye for typos!) * Able to review data and pull out key insights * Collaborative, but must be capable of working independently * Fluent in Spanish a plus * Interest in working in the nonprofit sector or aging services a plus Please provide examples of published writing and/or social media projects Additional Information * 15-20 hours a week, 3 days a week (days are flexible). This is not a remote position. * 2-3 months minimum starting in September/October 2017 * Our office is located East Harlem Class credit can be given To apply, please email your resume and cover letter to Arianna at defelicea@carterburdennetwork.org
10029.title: Social Media and Marketing Intern

Mentors and mentees meet in a supervised environment at a set time and location. All sites are supported by MUSA Program Managers who work directly with Site Supervisors at each location to ensure that the programs run smoothly. Contact: volunteering@mentoringusa.org All mentors must be 18 and older and willing to undergo a background check and screening. Step 1: Visit Mentoring USA's website: http://www.mentoringusa.org Step 2: Complete the Mentor Application: http://www.mentoringusa.org/become_a_mentor/Mentor_Application Step 3: Attend our New Mentor Training.
10029.title: Mentoring is rewarding - Become a mentor with Mentoring USA – East Harlem.

10029.description: Travel Unity has teamed up with Citizen Schools ( citizenschools.org ) to introduce middle school students to the amazing opportunities that exist within the world of travel. As a volunteer Citizen Teacher, you will lead/co-lead a 10-week apprenticeship program in East Harlem to help develop students' 21st century job skills through the prism of travel. Trainings start in late August and teaching sessions end in December. We understand that you might have conflicts, so don't let a date or two stop you from reaching out. It’s no exaggeration that having good role models can change the trajectory of a child's life. Through the 10 weeks, you will work alongside a Teaching Fellow to educate young people about the endless opportunities that exist within our rapidly changing global economy. Travel Unity will support you throughout the way, working with you to help make a real difference in these children's lives. Your participation will help increase their self-awareness, enhance their world perspective, and foster their independence. Imagine the lasting impact you could have on these young lives! For more information , contact trish@travelunity.org
10029.title: Travel Bloggers, Enthusiasts Volunteers needed: Share your love of travel with tweens!

10029.description: Dear Manhattan and Queens folks, On behalf of the Mount Sinai Sexual Assault and Violence Intervention (SAVI) Program, I wanted to invite you to join us in eradicating sexual and intimate partner violence from our communities. New York City needs you! By joining our roster of volunteer Emergency Department (ED) Advocates it is possible to have an impact. An ED Advocate is trained to provide support and advocacy for survivors in emergency departments, so they don’t have to face the difficult decisions, emotions and follow-up procedures alone. SAVI ED Advocates helped more than 500 survivors in New York City Emergency Departments last year- that’s almost 2 survivors a day! We hope you or someone you know may be interested in becoming a Volunteer Emergency Department Advocate. Those interested should call (212) 423-2151 or email savi@mssm.edu for the next steps. In your email please include your telephone number and the general best day(s) and time(s) to reach you at that number. Interviews will be held from July - October and those accepted into the program will begin training in mid-October. More information is also available at our website: please visit www.mssm.edu/savi . Thank you so much for your help and we hope to hear from you! Your friends at The Mount Sinai SAVI Team
10029.title: Help Survivors of Sexual and Intimate Partner Violence - Manhattan and Queens Residents Needed!

10029.description: DREAM, an award-winning youth development program, is seeking dedicated volunteers to serve as College Success Mentors for our Alumni Program, known as the Legends Program. Designed to assist first-year students in their transition to college, volunteer College Success Mentors will provide support and resources intended to increase academic success, build character, and improve student engagement with their university. What You’ll Do Deliver support and guidance as students work to form communities, get involved on campus, and access campus resources. Communicate student’s progress with DREAM staff. Serve as a role model and build positive relationships with mentee. What We’re Looking For Strong understanding of the challenges low-income students face as they transition to college life; Possess enthusiasm, empathy, and patience; Ability to make a year-long commitment; Previous experience working with young adults; Bachelor’s Degree. Benefits Gain invaluable experience and opportunities for professional development at an award winning youth development program; Receive an optional professional reference upon completion of your service term; Join an incredible community of passionate staff and volunteers. Hours Hours will vary. Volunteer mentors commit to communicating with their mentee once a week, meeting in person once a month, and participating in a program at DREAM once a semester. Commitment One year. DREAM provides equal opportunity for all volunteers.
10029.title: College Success Mentor

10029.description: Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
10029.title: Become a reading partner- make a lifelong impact on a child (PS 38 Roberto Clemente, NYC)

10029.description: The Emergency Department Ambassador (EDA) provides comfort and conversations to patinets and families in the Emergency Room. They assist in distributing lunch trays to patients that do not have food restrictions, make certain patients have a pillow, a blanket and other things that can improve their comfort in the emergency room. The goal of the EDA is to provide a friendly and helpful presence, and to be of assistance to the emergency room staff. The Ambassador can also escort family members to the cafeteria or other areas of the hospital, assist with phone charging, and even make certain the patient knows their nurses name. The EDA provides non-medical information. If you are kind and compassionate and feel comfortable assisting in the Emegency Room we could teach you to be an EDA. This position is available Monday - Friday from 12 noon to 3PM. We ask Ambassadors to serve at least one session per week.
10029.title: Hospital Emergency Room Ambassador

10027.description: Harlem Educational Activities Fund, Inc. HEAF is seeking dedicated individuals to serve as academic coaches to providing tutoring and support to our College Quest (High School) students, grades 9-11. About HEAF: The Harlem Educational Activities Fund, Inc. (HEAF) is a comprehensive not-for-profit supplemental education and youth development organization that supports and assists dedicated students to develop the intellectual curiosity, academic ability, social values and personal resiliency they need to ensure success in school, career and life. HEAF identifies scholars in middle school and supports them until they are successfully admitted to four-year colleges through a variety of after-school, Saturday and summer programs. Academic Coach Position Summary: HEAF seeks talented, passionate individuals to work with our high school students to ensure their academic success. HEAF’s College Quest program operates on weekdays from 4:30-6:30pm. Academic Coaches are asked to make at least a one hour/week commitment for a minimum of one semester. Academic Coaches provide assistance in core subjects such as Math, English, Science, and Social Studies. Coaches are matched with students based on the coach’s skills in specific subject areas and the student’s needs. Academic Coach Responsibilities: Assess and assist students in at least one of the core subjects Assist students with homework, projects, and test preparation Evaluate and record student progress Attend and participate in scheduled tutor orientation & training meetings Communicate academic progress to program staff Complete and submit required documentation Create a rich learning environment that aids in instructing students with various learning styles General Requirements: Desire to work with and motivate high school students to achieve academic success Some College or B.A. (Masters students in Education encouraged to apply) Advanced skills in Mathematics, English Language Arts, Science, Social Studies, and/or SAT Test Prep Experience tutoring high school students Strong work ethic and professional values Strong interpersonal skills Willingness to promote HEAF educational and youth development philosophy. Ability to work collaboratively with the HEAF staff Ability and willingness to commit to academic year Bilingual (Spanish/English) candidates are highly encouraged to apply. *This position is unpaid
10027.title: High School Academic Coach

10027.description: HEAF is seeking dedicated individuals to serve as academic coaches to providing tutoring and support and/or to serve as Teacher’s Assistants for our High Expectations (Middle School) students, grades 6-8. About HEAF: The Harlem Educational Activities Fund, Inc. (HEAF) is a comprehensive not-for-profit supplemental education and youth development organization that supports and assists dedicated students to develop the intellectual curiosity, academic ability, social values and personal resiliency they need to ensure success in school, career and life. HEAF identifies scholars in middle school and supports them until they are successfully admitted to four-year colleges through a variety of after-school, Saturday and summer programs. Academic Coach Position Summary: HEAF seeks talented, passionate individuals to work with our middle school students to ensure their academic success. HEAF’s High Expectations tutoring program operates on Saturdays from 2:30-3:30pm after our Saturday Academy program. Academic Coaches are asked to make a minimum of a one hour/week commitment for a minimum of one semester. Please note that additional hours and responsibilities may be available depending on the interests of the academic coach. Academic Coaches provide assistance in core subjects such as Math, English, Science, and Social Studies. Coaches are matched with students based on the coach’s skills in specific subject areas and the student’s needs. Academic Coach Responsibilities: Assess and assist students in at least one of the core subjects Assist students with homework, projects, and test preparation Evaluate and record student progress Attend and participate in scheduled tutor orientation & training meetings Communicate academic progress to program staff Complete and submit required documentation Create a rich learning environment that aids in instructing students with various learning styles Teaching Assistant Position Summary HEAF seeks individuals who have a strong desire to work with middle school students to achieve academic success. As a classroom assistant, you will work alongside one of our teachers to provide supplemental support to our students. Teaching Assistants are asked to make a two hour/week commitment for a minimum of one semester. Teaching Assistants will work alongside our teachers for our Saturday Academic Elective classes. Teacher’s Assistant Responsibilities: Assist with lunch supervision Create and maintain a positive classroom culture while using effective classroom management strategies Encourage positive student behavior that promotes character development Maintain meaningful positive rapport with parents and students General Requirements for both positions: Some College or B.A. (Masters students in Education encouraged to apply) Advanced skills in Mathematics, English Language Arts, Science, Social Studies, and/or SAT Test Prep Experience tutoring middle school students Strong work ethic and interpersonal skills Willingness to promote HEAF educational and youth development philosophy. Ability to work collaboratively with the HEAF staff Bilingual (Spanish/English) candidates are highly encouraged to apply. *This position is unpaid
10027.title: Middle School Academic Coach and Teaching Assistant - Harlem

10024.description: Intergenerational Chess at DOROT Share your love of the game and bring a smile to a senior. \"One of the best things about playing chess with Mr. B is how excited we are to see each other.\" -Zach, age 13 Registration is still open on a rolling basis! Fall/Winter: Sept. 18 - Dec. 18 from 4:00-5:30pm Students and DOROT Seniors will get to know each other and play chess together. Refreshments will be served. Free. Requirements: for 6th - 12th grade students must commit to all sessions understand the game of chess understand the different chess pieces and how to move them Intergenerational Chess at DOROT is sponsored by the Targoff family and friends
10024.title: Intergenerational Chess - Youth Needed to Play Chess with Seniors

10024.description: A special intergenerational reading adventure for 3rd and 4th graders. We are still accepting students on a rolling basis! Students spend time reading and discussing books with older adults. The program is ideal for youth to gain encouragement to reach for a book and spend time discussing books. students will nurture their natural love of reading and engage in a variety of fun and creative intergenerational activities. The group will read aloud a few books over the course of 14 sessions and discuss the major themes of the books respecting other’s differences and the value of kindness. Great food and art activities will follow. 2017 Dates: September 13 (orientation for youth,) September 27 October 4, 18, 25 November 1, 8, 15, 29 December 6, 13, 20 Jan 3, 10, 17 3rd and 4th graders can register online at: http://www.dorotusa.org/book. Only 12 spaces are available for youth. Parents need a pre-phone interview. For more information, please contact Shai Rosenfeld at srosenfeld@dorotusa.org or 917-441-5051
10024.title: Reading Adventure for 3rd and 4th Grade Students

10025.description: Top Honors is a non-profit educational organization that provides free math tutoring to NYC 5th, 6th, 7th, and 8th-graders. Tutoring takes place on Saturdays and Wednesday evenings at a school on the Upper West Side. New volunteer orientation and training sessions take place on a rolling basis. To receive an invitation, please submit an application here. Frequently asked questions about the TH volunteer experience can be found on our website. All tutoring sessions take place on the Upper West Side in Manhattan on the following days and times: Session 1: Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 12 p.m. Session 2: Saturdays from 1 p.m. to 3 p.m. Session 3: Wednesdays from 6:30 p.m. to 8 p.m. Volunteers may be professionals, advanced high school, college, or graduate students (community service credit is available). Applicants should be available on Saturdays for two hours starting at 10 a.m. or 1:00 p.m. or on Wednesdays from 6:30 - 8 pm, like math, and enjoy working with students in the middle school age group (10-14 years). No prior experience is necessary. A note on volunteer commitment: Tutors attend 2-3 Saturdays from October and May, which includes holidays and school breaks. Attending 22 out of 27 scheduled sessions will meet this requirement. To apply, submit an online application at www.tophonors.org/volunteer. Upon receipt, Top Honors will contact the candidate directly.
10025.title: Do you love MATH? Volunteer MATH Tutors needed!

10025.description: Whether you're great, good or fair at Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM), you can help make an impact on inner-city youth. Here's how: The Parris Foundation S.T.E.M.ulating Minds Weekend Enrichment Program has returned for the Fall 2017 session. The program began after a successful summer pilot in 2012, and our subsequent programs have grown to continue to serve middle school students and high school students . With the growing impact on the community, we need your support to continue to bring STEM to our middle school and high school youth throughout New York City. As we expand to more locations to serve more youth, there is a growing need for volunteers! How we do it: The Parris Foundation curriculum combines innovative and interactive software and teaching techniques with hand-ons interdisciplinary experiments and activities to keep our students engaged with their passion for science and math! About The Parris Foundation: The Parris Foundation is dedicated to promoting educational opportunities and fostering awareness in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) through scholarships and community outreach programs. The Parris Foundation's S.T.E.M.ulating Minds: Weekend Enrichment Programs provide extended learning opportunities to supplement and enhance in-school learning.
10025.title: Fall 2017 - S.T.E.M.ulating Minds Weekend Enrichment Program

10025.description: Join the West Side YMCA on October 21st at Riverside Park in effort to fight childhood obesity! Register today to volunteer in the below areas: Registration Boo Zone Volunteer (Pumpkin Patch or Arts & Crafts) Water Station Breakfast Station Gear Check Hype Team Course Marshall Breakdown & Clean Up For more information please email Bianca Perez at bperez@ymcanyc.org Thank you in advance for your support!
10025.title: fairlife Fit for All 5K
10025.org: YMCA of Greater New York - West Side

10022.description: I need help to navigate the workings of a non profit. A person who has organizational skills, knowledge about non profits and most important, a big heart! I am also looking for a photographer who has the flexibility to visit nursing homes with me. You do not need to be a professional photographer but should know how to take a great photo and video. It would be a big plus if you have a camera.
10022.title: Looking for a right hand person who can take this journey with me!

10023.description: It's Breaking Ground's largest fundraising effort of the year! Please join us for our annual Celebrating Home and Community Gala, as we map the way from street to home for New York City's most vulnerable population. Proceeds from our event will be used to support the housing development and street outreach programs that have distinguished our organization since 1990. We hope you can be a part of it. Volunteers will be asked to help with registration, crowd control, takeaway items and clean up. Volunteers will also be asked to dress in business casual/cocktail attire. For questions, please reach out to Erin at ewilliams@breakingground.org.
10023.title: Breaking Ground’s Celebrating Home & Community Gala

10023.description: Volunteer opportunity - ACS Making Strides Against Breast Cancer/ Central Park Volunteers Needed! Are you looking to get more involved with your local community? Do you enjoy working with and meeting new people? Are you passionate about helping others and finishing the fight against cancer? If this sounds like you, the American Cancer Society needs you! The Making Strides Against Breast Cancer Walk of Central Park is one of the largest breast cancer awareness events in the nation. The money raised through the event helps save many lives by funding groundbreaking breast cancer research, providing free comprehensive information and support, and helping people take steps to reduce their risk of the disease or find it early when it’s most treatable. As the largest voluntary health organization in the country, we count on volunteers and volunteer driven organizations, agencies and companies to help make this event run smoothly and efficiently. The walk is on October 15th, 2017 located in Central Park and we need your help! Our volunteers help with important event details such as check in, water stations, information, and more. You’re there to help make the event truly special and to join, encourage, and support those in the fight against breast cancer! With just a few hours, you can help make a difference in countless lives and create a world with more birthdays! If interested, please contact our Event Manager Denise Solorzano, at Denise.Solorzano@cancer.org or by phone at 212-237-3813.
10023.title: Making Strides Against Breast Cancer-- Central Park Volunteer

10021.description: Sparkidz is a recreational program for children with special needs. We operate every Saturday on the UES from 10am-4pm and are currently looking for devoted and outstanding volunteers. You can learn more about us at www.sparkidz.org
10021.title: Volunteer with Sparkidz Saturdays

10021.description: Friendly Visiting is a program that pairs volunteers with homebound seniors to provide company and friendship. We ask volunteers to commit to visit their senior match one time per week for a period of six months or more. We are seeking volunteers to visit seniors who live between 96th and 145th street on the east side of Manhattan. If you are interested in learning more about this opportunity, please reply with your phone number and the best time to reach you. Thank you so much!
10021.title: Friendly Visiting- East Harlem

10021.description: Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, widely recognized as one of New York's premiere human services providers, is a 123 year old settlement house that provides an extensive array of effective and integrated services on the East Side of Manhattan. We are seeking volunteers to assist older adults with improving their technology skills during our Computer Practice Lab. Volunters are needed to facilitate the practice lab from 3:00-4:30 weekly on either Monday or Friday for a minimum of four months starting on either September 8 or September 11.
10021.title: Assist Older Adults in a Computer Lab

10036.description: Join Shatterproof as we Rise Up Against Addiction! Shatterproof, a national nonprofit organization dedicated to ending the devastation addiction causes families, is in need of volunteers at our Rise Up Against Addiction 5K in New York City!! If you've been touched by addiction, then you know how devastating this disease really is. Together, we can make a difference! We have lots of different positions to choose from and this event is sure to be a fun experience for all involved!
10036.title: Rise Up Against Addiction 5K NYC

10036.description: Were looking for enthusiastic and friendly dancers who have experience working with or teaching dance to kids ages 3-18. Kids will be separated by age, and you will be able to choose your preffered age group if it's available.
10036.title: Kids Dance Teachers Needed!!

10036.description: We are looking for someone with experience teaching or working with children, and is an experienced dancer. Should be personable, friendly and a good communicator.
10036.title: Kids Hip-hop dance teacher

10036.description: We are looking for someone with experience teaching dance to children. Dancers who are interested in gaining teaching experience and have worked with children in other capacities are welcome to apply as well.
10036.title: Kids Ballet Teacher

10036.description: Centro NYC, a non-profit organization serving the immigrant community in New York City, seeks a volunteer ESL teacher for its fall term, beginning immediately and continuing through mid-December. However, we encourage you continue to volunteer with us in the following semester. Classroom English teaching experience is welcome. You will be partnered with and mentored by an experienced teacher. Time commitment: one night per week teaching plus the time required for lesson preparation (usually every other week.) Classes meet Mondays, Wednesdays, and Thursdays from 6:15-9:00 p.m. in midtown Manhattan. We have at least one opening on Wednesday evening to work with our intermediate to advanced students, all adults, but other opportunities may be available. Please respond by email to Danielle at info@CentroNYC.org. Include your resume and tell us the evening(s) that you're available for teaching.
10036.title: Volunteer English / ESL Teacher to Adults -- Immediate Opportunity!

10036.description: Centro NYC, a non-profit organization serving the immigrant community in New York City, seeks a volunteer ESL teacher for its fall term, beginning immediately and continuing through mid-December. However, we encourage you continue to volunteer with us in the following semester. Classroom English teaching experience is welcome. You will be partnered with and mentored by an experienced teacher. Time commitment: one night per week teaching plus the time required for lesson preparation (usually every other week.) Classes meet Mondays, Wednesdays, and Thursdays from 6:15-9:00 p.m. in midtown Manhattan. We have at least one opening on Wednesday evening to work with our intermediate to advanced students, but other opportunities may be available. Please respond by email to Danielle at info@CentroNYC.org. Include your resume and tell us the evening(s) that you're available for teaching.
10036.title: Adult English / ESL Teacher – VOLUNTEER NEEDED!

10036.description: The Lupus Research Alliance is hosting the 14th Annual New York City Walk with Us to Cure Lupus on Saturday, October 14th at the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum. Volunteers are the key to success and we are looking for energetic indivdiuals! Whether you want to walk, aren't able to walk, or just want to help, there's something for you. Some examples of volunteer opportunities are food & beverage distrubition to the participants, registration/check-in and cheering on our Walkers. Walk Day volunteers will receive a Volunteer T-Shirt and the gratitude of the Lupus Research Alliance staff. We hope to see you there! Visit our official website at www.lupuswalknyc.org or call (646) 884-6030 for more information.
10036.title: 2017 New York City Walk with Us to Cure Lupus

10036.description: Hola! Somos una organización sin fines de lucro que ayuda a la comunidad inmigrante latina y no latina de Nueva York en el aprendizaje del idioma inglés, en la preparación para el examen de ciudadanía estadounidense y en el desarrollo de otras actividades de empoderamiento para la comunidad inmigrante. También ofrecemos clases de español para no hispanohablantes, con lo cual contribuimos además a la difusión de la cultura y valores hispanos en los Estados Unidos. Estamos a la búsqueda de profesores de Español (voluntarios) para nuestras clases de Otoño 2017 (septiembre - diciembre 2017) que empiezan el 18 de septiembre. Las clases son una vez por semana de 6:15 pm a 9:00 pm. Esta es una posición de voluntariado (sin pago). Habrá una sesión de entrenamiento previo al inicio de clases el jueves 14 de septiembre de 2017 en la noche. Si te gusta ayudar a la gente y a la comunidad por favor comunícate con nosotros respondiendo este aviso. Muchas gracias!
10036.title: Volunteer Spanish Teachers / Profesores de Español (voluntarios)

10036.description: On Halloween (Tuesday, October 31, 2017) we’re throwing a Halloween Karaoke Party for our residents at our Times Square location, which serves a mix of low-income and formerly chronically homeless single adults, many of whom have special needs. This is just another one of our community-building events that we like to put on for our residents while engaging with the surrounding community. Volunteers will be asked to help set up, serve food/drinks, and clean up afterwards, but we also want to encourage you to participate in our fun and games. If this sounds like something you’d like to be a part of, we'd love to have you!
10036.title: Halloween Karaoke Party at the Times Square

10036.description: We're looking for enthusiastic, driven individuals aged 16 and older to help make our BT5K Breakthrough for Brain Tumors event a huge success. Lend a hand out on the course, at the event site, with pre- or post-event activities, as part of the planning committee, or in one of many other ways. And don't worry... ABTA staff will be with you all the way through training and event day guidance.
10036.title: BT5K Breakthrough for Brain Tumors Run & Walk: New York City

10036.description: We are starting a new program to help immigrants study for TASC (Test Assessing Secondary Completion), formerly known as GED. We need volunteers to help and run the English writing and reading comprehension classes; and also Math classes. There are various volunteer opportunities. Please do not hesitate to contact us with any queries. Any help you can provide is valuable to us.
10036.title: Volunteers needed to teach English and Math classes

10036.description: Volunteers needed to help out with general office organisation, administrative work and marketing. Any help is appreciated.
10036.title: Volunteers needed for admin and general office

10017.description: My name is Logan Moore and I’m the Events Manager for the American Liver Foundation, Greater New York Division. We will be holding our 17th Annual Honors Gala on Thursday, October 5, 2017 at The Roosevelt Hotel in New York City, and we need wonderful volunteers to help make the evening unforgettable! We currently need volunteers from 5pm- 9pm to help with set-up, registration, greeting, raffles, fund the mission, and clean-up. Depending on how the evening goes, the clean-up may run a little past 9pm. More information can be provided upon request, but anyone interested in volunteering can reach me directly at my email: lmoore@liverfoundation.org Please let me know if you are available to assist in any capacity on this day. We would love to have you!
10017.title: American Liver Foundation's 17th Annual Honors Gala
10017.org: American Liver Foundation Greater New York Division

10014.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Tutoring: How YOU Can Help During the GO School Saturday program, a professional teacher models a lesson, activity or project to a classroom of students. Volunteer tutors continue to work with small groups of (2) to (4) students on the lesson providing individualized attention which allows the students to thrive. Tutor Responsibilities Tutor small group of students in grades 1 st-8 th who are in need of academic intervention under Head Teacher’s guidance Punctual and consistent attendance; no more than 3 absences permitted per session. (Session 1: Oct-Dec, Session 2: Jan-April) Actively and enthusiastically participate - supporting instruction and engagement Help prepare, record and put away classroom materials Ongoing communication with Head Teacher regarding children’s progress &/or concerns, and with the Director of Community Engagement regarding overall volunteer experience. Time Commitment Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 14 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Attend mandatory orientation and training prior to start of session. *You can choose to be a Committed Volunteer to come each Saturday with 3 allowed absences per session, or a Floater Volunteer to come on the Saturdays that you are available. GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations You can choose to tutor our students at one of the following 6 locations: Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications College students, professionals, retirees, and high school students in good academic standing. Commitment to and belief in all children’s ability to succeed and thrive Professional work habits Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. 10014.title: Help a Child Love to Learn: Volunteer Tutor with GO Project!

10014.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Programming: How YOU Can Help GO Schoolis a focused, seven-month Saturday program with a staff of certified teachers and skilled volunteer tutors. Students attend on Saturdays between October and April for a half-day of focused academic skill-building. Professional teachers lead lessons, support volunteer tutors, and communicate with parents to keep them informed about their child’s progress. Volunteer tutors commit to a semester of volunteering in a classroom and mentor their students to provide consistent and individualized needed to succeed. Volunteer translators provide critical communication support between our GO families and our staff. Interpreters are responsible for translating English into Chinese (both Mandarin and Cantonese) in order for our program to communicate with our families regarding program updates and their child’s academic & social-emotional progress/needs. Specific Translator duties will include: Saturdays Assist with parent meetings, workshops and orientations for Chinese speaking families. Provide interpretation for our families, including any cultural/linguistic references that may need to be explained. Maintain our families’ right to confidentiality. Collaborate with GO Staff, Volunteer Manager, Head Teachers and GO Families Staff to address and respond to our students’/ families’ needs. Time Commitment The position would require a commitment to our GO School Saturday program. We can accommodate a semester schedule or a full year commitment. Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 13 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications: Excellent verbal and written communication skills. Interest in strength-based collaborative work, education and social services. Ability to speak both Mandarin and Cantonese is preferred. Prior experience in simultaneous and consecutive interpretation is a plus. Personal Attributes: The ideal candidate is exceptionally intelligent, warm, engaging and energetic. He or she also: Sees the possibilities as opposed to the obstacles and is creative and tenacious in solving problems. Enjoys working with others in a collaborative, creative environment. Has a strong work ethic and high standards for his/her own work and the work of others; is flexible and has a lively sense of humor. Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with the GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/ High school transcript (for HS students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2 . The online application form can also be found on the GO Project website: goprojectnyc.org under \"Get Involved\" and \"Volunteer Opportunities.\" If you have any questions or would like more information about the available volunteer positions, please contact Emily Ong, Community Engagement Program Manager, at eong@goprojectnyc.org.

10014.title: Saturday Chinese Translators Needed!

10014.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Tutoring: How YOU Can Help During the GO School Saturday program, a professional teacher models a lesson, activity or project to a classroom of students. Volunteer tutors continue to work with small groups of (2) to (4) students on the lesson providing individualized attention which allows the students to thrive. 10014.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Programming: How YOU Can Help GO Schoolis a focused, seven-month Saturday program with a staff of certified teachers and skilled volunteer tutors. Students attend on Saturdays between October and April for a half-day of focused academic skill-building. Professional teachers lead lessons, support volunteer tutors, and communicate with parents to keep them informed about their child’s progress. Volunteer tutors commit to a semester of volunteering in a classroom and mentor their students to provide consistent and individualized needed to succeed. Volunteer translators provide critical communication support between our GO families and our staff. Interpreters are responsible for translating English into Chinese (both Mandarin and Cantonese) in order for our program to communicate with our families regarding program updates and their child’s academic & social-emotional progress/needs. Specific Translator duties will include: Saturdays Assist with parent meetings, workshops and orientations for Chinese speaking families. Provide interpretation for our families, including any cultural/linguistic references that may need to be explained. Maintain our families’ right to confidentiality. Collaborate with GO Staff, Volunteer Manager, Head Teachers and GO Families Staff to address and respond to our students’/ families’ needs. Time Commitment The position would require a commitment to our GO School Saturday program. We can accommodate a semester schedule or a full year commitment. Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 13 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications: Excellent verbal and written communication skills. Interest in strength-based collaborative work, education and social services. Ability to speak both Mandarin and Cantonese is preferred. Prior experience in simultaneous and consecutive interpretation is a plus. Personal Attributes: The ideal candidate is exceptionally intelligent, warm, engaging and energetic. He or she also: Sees the possibilities as opposed to the obstacles and is creative and tenacious in solving problems. Enjoys working with others in a collaborative, creative environment. Has a strong work ethic and high standards for his/her own work and the work of others; is flexible and has a lively sense of humor. Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with the GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/ High school transcript (for HS students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2 . The online application form can also be found on the GO Project website: goprojectnyc.org under \"Get Involved\" and \"Volunteer Opportunities.\" If you have any questions or would like more information about the available volunteer positions, please contact Emily Ong, Community Engagement Program Manager, at eong@goprojectnyc.org.

10014.description: The National Audubon Society’s volunteer program aims to inspire lifelong stewardship of our environment and communities, providing individuals the opportunity to develop skills needed for a successful career in conservation. Currently, volunteer opportunities are being offered in the area of Environmental Education.  Audubon invites you to become a volunteer with Audubon New York’s premier environmental education program, For the Birds! ( FTB!) NYC.  For the Birds! is a place-based elementary education program that teaches environmental awareness and appreciation of nature through the study of birds. During multiple visits, students in grades two through six learn about their local, natural environment through indoor and outdoor lessons, field trips, and a conservation project designed to provide or enhance bird habitat in the local community.   For the Birds! volunteers will assist with the implementation of the FTB! program in New York City schools and camps throughout all five boroughs.  S/he will teach this program to multiple classes / summer camps in New York City and will also assist the FTB! Program Director with administrative duties related to the delivery and expansion of the program.  This includes, but is not limited to: curriculum development and revision, materials preparation and inventory, school set up, follow up and wrap up, and other administrative duties as needed. Volunteers will work closely with the FTB! Program Director to inspire a new generation of conservationists through the study of birds.   Interns will gain experience s in both formal and non-formal environmental education and learn valuable and transferable skills such as project management, curriculum development, volunteer management, and community engagement.
10014.title: Audubon NY's For the Birds! Education Program

10014.description: JOIN HUDSON RIVER PARK’S HRPGreenTeam Gain meaningful experience working with like-minded individuals looking to beautify and maintain Hudson River Park’s picturesque waterside landscape! This volunteer program is an exciting opportunity for community members to nurture their inner green thumb alongside their neighbors while improving public green space. Members of the HRPGreenTeam will work with our seasoned horticulture staff and participate in landscape enhancement activities including planting, weeding, pruning, mulching, trimming of ornamental grasses, addition of soil amendments, cleaning of vegetation beds, and other general gardening tasks. When: One Saturday of every month from March-October; 10AM-1PM March 25th April 15th May6th June 3rd June 17th July 15th July 29th August 12th August 26th September 9th October 21st November 18th What we provide: Safety and horticulture training, tools and equipment, Hudson River Park Volunteer T-Shirt, water, snacks, FUN! Can’t commit to all of our events? No problem! RSVP to any or all of the Green Team volunteer days. Locations and activities will vary each month, and volunteers will get to experience the Park from a whole new perspective throughout the seasons. Space is limited, so RSVP today to volunteer@fohrp.org or call for more information (347-515-2242)
10014.title: HRP GreenTeam at Hudson River Park!

10280.description: We Need Volunteers! Gift of Life helps children and adults suffering from leukemia, lymphoma, and other blood cancers find donors for bone marrow and blood stem cell transplants. Would you like to: Support a great cause? Share your talent and energy? Earn community service hours? Have a lot of fun while doing all the above? We need volunteers for: setup, registration, clean-up, t-shirt distribution, water stations, course monitoring, and much more! In addition, we provide community service hours for the time that you donate to us! For more information, contact Sarah Weiss at sweiss@giftoflife.org.
10280.title: Gift of Life "Steps for Life" of New York City

10019.description: The National MS Society is looking for packet support volunteers to help the day before Bike MS: New York City! Packet support volunteers will be needed on Saturday, October 21 at Pier 92/94 in Manhattan. Bike MS: New York City is a unique experience - the 30 mile route around Manhattan is completely traffic free. The 50 and 100 mile rides allow cyclists to ride through the Holland Tunnel traffic free. More than 500 volunteers are needed to make this event a success. If you are interested in volunteering, please review the position below and register online here: www.bikeMSnyc.org Packet Support/Pick Up Team Date: Saturday, October 21, 2017 Location: Pier 92/94 - Manhattan Time: 10:00am-2:00pm Description: Volunteers will assist with the packet support/pick up process the day before Bike MS: NYC. Volunteers will pull rider packets and keep the packet system organized. This is a supportive admin volunteer role that is perfect for organized individuals. Volunteers will work along with NMSS staff. If you have any questions, please contact: Amber Young - Manager, Volunteer Engagement at Amber.Young@nmss.org or 212-453-3258
10019.title: Packet Support Volunteers Needed for Bike MS: NYC!
10019.org: National MS Society - New York City

10019.description: The National MS Society is looking for volunteers to help with pre-event set up for Bike MS: New York City! Pre-event set up volunteers will be needed on Saturday, October 21 at Pier 92/94 in Manhattan. Bike MS: New York City is a unique experience - the 30 mile route around Manhattan is completely traffic free. The 50 and 100 mile rides allow cyclists to ride through the Holland Tunnel traffic free. More than 500 volunteers are needed to make this event a success. If you are interested in volunteering, please review the position below and register online here: www.bikeMSnyc.org Pre-Event Set Up Team Date: Saturday, October 21, 2017 Location: Pier 92/94 - Manhattan Time: 10:00am-2:00pm Description: Volunteers will assist with the setup of tables, chairs, materials and signage. You must be able to lift boxes, stand and walk for long periods of time. No seated positions available If you have any questions, please contact: Amber Young - Manager, Volunteer Engagement at Amber.Young@nmss.org or 212-453-3258
10019.title: Pre-Event Set Up Volunteers Needed for Bike MS: NYC!
10019.org: National MS Society - New York City

10019.description: The National MS Society is looking for volunteers to help with our upcoming event - Bike MS New York City! Bike MS New York City will be held on Sunday, October 22 at Pier 92/94 in Manhattan. Bike MS: New York City is a unique experience - the 30 mile route around Manhattan is completely traffic free. The 50 and 100 mile rides allow cyclists to ride through the Holland Tunnel traffic free. More than 300 volunteers are needed to make this event a success! Groups and individuals of all ages and abilities are invited to volunteer. We are always looking for youth clubs, corporate and service-oriented community groups to lend a hand before, during, and after our events. There is only one requirement: a desire to end MS now! If you are interested in volunteering, please review the positions below and register online here: www.bikeMSnyc.org Bike MS New York City - Volunteer Positions Pre-Event Support Team Date: Saturday, October 21, 2017 Description: Volunteers will assist with the setup of tables, chairs, materials and signage. You must be able to lift boxes, stand and walk for long periods of time. No seated positions available. Packet Pick Up Team Date: Saturday, October 21, 2017 Time: 10:00am-2:00pm Description: Volunteers will assist with packet pick up the day before Bike MS: NYC. Volunteers will pull rider packets and keep the system organized. Volunteers will work along with NMSS staff. Bike Parking Team Date: Sunday, October 22, 2017 Time: 5:00am-11:00am (Shift 1) / 8:30am-1:30pm (Shift 2) / 1:00pm-6:00pm (Shift 3) Description: Volunteers will provide support to the bike parking area and make sure that cyclists park their bikes in the correct location in the pier. Customer Service Team Date: Sunday, October 22, 2017 Time: 5:00am-9:00am Description: Volunteers will be pulling rider packets and helping the NMSS staff with general customer service. Event Day Support Team Date: Sunday, October 22, 2017 Time: Multiple Shifts Available Description: Volunteers will provide support to various participant areas including, but not limited to: Bag Check, Top Fundraiser Lounge and more! Food & Beverage Team Date: Sunday, October 22, 2017 Times/Shifts: General Food & Beverage - 8:00am-12:00pm (Shift 1) / 11:30am-3:00pm (Shift 2) / 2:30pm-6:00pm (Shift 3) Lunch Line Manager - 9:30am-2:30pm (Shift 1) / 2:00pm-6:00pm (Shift 2) Beer Garden - 9:30am-2:30pm (Shift 1) / 2:00pm-6:00pm (Shift 2) - VOLUNTEERS MUST BE 21+ Food Trucks - 5:00am-9:30am Description: Volunteers will provide support to our different Food & Beverage area which include general food & beverage, managing the lunch line, helping at the breakfast food trucks and managing the line at the beer garden Medal Distribution Team Date: Sunday, October 22, 2017 Time: 8:30am-1:00pm (Shift 1) / 12:30pm-5:30pm (Shift 2) Description: Volunteers will cheer on the cyclists as they cross the finish line and hand out Bike MS medals! Photography Team Date: Sunday, October 22, 2017 Time: 5:30am-8:00am Description: Volunteers will take photos of participants and sponsors at the event Rest Stop Support Team Date: Sunday, October 22, 2017 Times: Multiple Shifts Available Description: Volunteers will be assigned to one of the rest stops along the route to distribute water and cheer on walkers. Rest Stop Locations □ Inwood Hill Park, NY □ Weehawken, NJ □ Alpine, NJ □ Closter, NJ □ Englewood, NJ □ Congers, NY □ Garnerville, NY Site Set Up Team Date: Sunday, October 22, 2017 Time: 5:00am-9:00am Description: Volunteers will help with site set up the morning of the event. Heavy lifting is involved - no seated positions. Site Breakdown Team Date: Sunday, October 22, 2017 Time: 2:30pm-6:00pm Description: Volunteers will help take down signs, break down tables and pack up event items. Heavy lifting is involved - no seated positions. 10019.description: We match isolated and lonely seniors with volunteers in the community who make weekly visits in the senior’s home. The Friendly Visiting program is an opportunity to form rewarding relationships and ongoing companionship for both seniors and volunteers. Seniors and their visitor can converse and enjoy the company, take part in activities like going to cafes and museums, share stories, learn new skills, and a variety of other things based on the desires of the companions. You will be matched with a senior who has a similar personality and interests and you can decide together how to spend your time. Visits can easily fit into your schedule because matches are made based on your availability. We ask for a minimum commitment of 6 months or 1 year. Your time as a friendly visitor is invaluable, and you gain a new friend!
10019.title: Provide Companionship To Homebound & Isolated Senior - It is Only One Hour Per Week!!!
10019.org: Encore Community Services

10019.description: The National Chorale is a premier NYC choral organization, founded 49 years ago, made up of an Ensemble of professional singers and soloists. Our annual concert series is presented in David Geffen Hall at Lincoln Center. We also present choral performances in other NYC venues as well as at other local, national and international festivals and music events and conferences. We also have a K-12 music training program where we provide professional music teachers in local NYC public schools. Our Executive Director is underwater with her workload, some of which we would like to offload to Administrative / Clerical Assistants. Work ranges from researching items on the Internet, to answering phones, to preparing reports, to scheduling events and people, to occasionally running an errand, typing - letters and reports and input to our database, attending meetings, communicating with our audience members, Board Members, concert personnel, funders, sponsors and K-12 NYC school administrators and teachers. Folks who have worked in the corporate environment with experienced office skills would be ideal. Office is in midtown Manhattan (Broadway & West 51st Street. Friendly office environment. Prefer a minimum of 20 hours per week, but we will work with you to design a schedule that is comfortable for you. We really need your help and like most nonprofit organizations, cannot afford to hire the support staff we require. BTW, one of the perks for our volunteers is that they are provided with two tickets to every Lincoln Center concert, and more if needed! Come join us and know that you will be making a real impact with a deserving nonprofit organization!
10019.title: Administrative / Clerical Help
10019.org: National Chorale

10018.description: The Step Up program is a six month goal focused mentoring/ coaching program fro high school students. The goal of the program is to enhance self-confidence and self- esteem which then leads to positive change in the lives of the students. In order to be a mentor you must be 24 or older. For further information please contact Alexandria at Alex@nyunlockingfutures.org / 212-791-4927 ext #263.
10018.title: Male or Female Mentors for our "Step Up" program!

10018.description: America Needs You fights for economic mobility for ambitious, first generation college students. We do this by providing transformative mentorship and intensive career development. Our flagship Fellows Program is a two-year, intensive mentoring and professional training program where first-generation students (\"Fellows\") are paired with young professional volunteers. Our New York program workshops take place in Manhattan and Brooklyn. Career Coaches work with college students during Saturday sessions to build their professional skills and help them realize their career potential. ANY curriculum covers all kinds of professional development topics from resume preparation and interview etiquette to giving and receiving feedback and managing up. At workshops, Career Coaches typically participate in group or one-on-one work with Fellows; for example, writing and reviewing a cover letter or building a pros/cons list for deciding between two internships. Please complete the survey below to be contacted about volunteering at an upcoming workshop: https://newyorkneedsyou.wufoo.com/forms/rn5685a0sqkdux/
10018.title: Volunteer to mentor ambitious first-generation college students!

10018.description: Global Green NY is looking for volunteers to help with our food donation work this summer. Volunteer opportunities are for food donation pick-ups in Midtown Manhattan on weekday nights (during typical resutrant closing time), where food will then be transported to food banks and shelters for those in need. http://www.globalgreen.org/getinvolved/ Ideally volunteers: For food rescue volunteers, the only qualifications are that they are punctual, reliable and able to carry 20+ lbs of food.
10018.title: New York GGUSA Volunteer

10038.description: Volunteer with Food Bank For New York City at the 2017 Food Network & Cooking Channel New York City Wine & Food Festival presented by Coca-Cola! We are looking for culinary students, graduates and those with professional culinary experience for the 2017 New York City Wine and Food Festival (NYCWFF) that is on Oct 12-15, 2017. We have over 70 events and 500+ culinary volunteer opportunities over this four-day event! Culinary volunteers gain experience in a range of events, from high-volume production to catering intimate gatherings. NYCWFF offers a great opportunity to make connections in the industry and showcase their talents for thousands of avid food and wine lovers, and it is a great addition to any resume. You are welcome to sign up individually or with a group. Requirements for all culinary support volunteers: 1. Professional culinary experience OR Current culinary student 2. Chef's coat 3. Knife Set with: Paring knife, Serrated knife, Chef knife, Peeler 4. All volunteers MUST be 18 or over Interested? Express your interest by going to foodbanknyc.wufoo.com/forms/zr0j6op0yes4ft/ If you do not have a culinary background, and would like to particpate as an EVENT support volunteer, you cando so by going to volunteer.foodbanknyc.org/nycwff2017 About the Food Bank Food Bank For New York City has been the city’s major hunger-relief organization working to end hunger throughout the five boroughs for more than 30 years. As one of the country's largest food banks, our mission is to end hunger in New York City by organizing food, information and support for community survival and dignity. As the city's hub for integrated food poverty assistance, the Food Bank tackles the hunger issue on three fronts - food distribution, income support and nutrition education - all strategically guided by its research.

10038.description: Drawing And Truth (DAT) is a Mentoring Program for Middle School and High School aged youth (13-18 year-olds) who have experienced or witnessed trauma. It runs throughout the school year from Mid-October to the end of June on Saturdays, typically from 12pm - 4pm. DAT is unlike typical Mentoring programs where Mentor & Mentee are assigned as pairs. Instead, DAT works as a social group where participants do fun and educational activities together including drawing/painting, crafts, ice skating, bike riding, etc. Mentors select and plan the activities based on the interests of the youth and the resources that are available in New York City! Being a DAT Mentor is one of the most fun and rewarding volunteer positions at Womankind because it is structured as a full year position with the chance to return cycle after cycle. Volunteers who are selected to be a DAT Mentor develop lasting connections with the youth and with fellow Mentors! For a full description of the group and expectations & requirements for the mentor role, please contact Kathy Tran at ktran@iamwk.org.
10038.title: Make a Difference in a Teenager's Life - Become a Drawing and Truth Mentor!
